user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_outline:
```c
static int lfs_file_outline(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    file->off = file->pos;
    lfs_alloc_ckpoint(lfs);
    int err = lfs_file_relocate(lfs, file);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    file->flags &= ~LFS_F_INLINE;
    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_outline:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected all explicit pointer declarators in the provided code that are not const-qualified: the function parameters (lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) in lfs_file_outline, the linked-list pointer members (struct lfs_mlist *next; and the lfs_t member declaration } *mlist;), the lookahead buffer (uint8_t *buffer;), and the file list pointer (struct lfs_file *next;). These are the explicit non-const pointer occurrences visible in the supplied snippets and therefore merit investigation under MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13.

I did not include: (a) pointer members that are already const-qualified (for example the cfg pointers are declared const in the snippets), (b) non-pointer scalar fields and typedefs (e.g., lfs_cache_t rcache) because no explicit pointer declarator appears in the shown code for them, and (c) other code outside the supplied snippets because it was not provided. If any typedefs (like lfs_cache_t) are actually pointer types in other parts of the codebase, or if functions called here modify objects pointed to by parameters, those places should be reviewed as well — but they are not directly visible in the supplied excerpts.
